kex_algorithms.name: curve25519-sha256@libssh.org
kex_algorithms.reason: Libssh.org Curve25519 (2014) w/ SHA-256; aligns with NIST >=128-bit recommendations.

kex_algorithms.name: diffie-hellman-group14-sha256
kex_algorithms.reason: 2048-bit MODP Group14 + SHA-256 (2014 refresh) satisfies NIST 112-bit baseline.

kex_algorithms.name: diffie-hellman-group16-sha512
kex_algorithms.reason: 4096-bit MODP Group16 + SHA-512 exceeds NIST Level 1 (112-bit) recommendations.

host_key_algorithms.name: ecdsa-sha2-nistp521
host_key_algorithms.reason: ECDSA P-521 (2009) ~256-bit, aligned with NIST Level 3.

host_key_algorithms.name: ssh-rsa
host_key_algorithms.reason: RSA with SHA-1 (2006); fails NIST guidance due to SHA-1 collisions.

host_key_algorithms.name: ssh-dss
host_key_algorithms.reason: DSA limited to 1024-bit modulus (1994); below NIST minimum 112-bit strength.

ciphers.name: aes256-ctr
ciphers.reason: AES-256 (2001) in CTR mode; 256-bit key gives long-term strength.

ciphers.name: aes128-ctr
ciphers.reason: AES-128 (2001) in CTR mode; 128-bit key remains strong when paired with modern MACs.

ciphers.name: aes256-cbc
ciphers.reason: AES-256 (2001) in CBC mode; padding oracles and lack of integrity make it risky.

ciphers.name: twofish256-cbc
ciphers.reason: Older (pre-2005) design with limited block size or known attacks (e.g., padding or keystream biases).

ciphers.name: aes128-cbc
ciphers.reason: AES-128 (2001) in CBC mode; prone to padding-oracle attacks without extra mitigations.

ciphers.name: twofish-cbc
ciphers.reason: Twofish (1998) but used in CBC without authentication; better options exist today.

ciphers.name: aes256-ctr
ciphers.reason: AES-256 (2001) in CTR mode; 256-bit key gives long-term strength.

ciphers.name: aes128-ctr
ciphers.reason: AES-128 (2001) in CTR mode; 128-bit key remains strong when paired with modern MACs.

ciphers.name: aes256-cbc
ciphers.reason: AES-256 (2001) in CBC mode; padding oracles and lack of integrity make it risky.

ciphers.name: twofish256-cbc
ciphers.reason: Older (pre-2005) design with limited block size or known attacks (e.g., padding or keystream biases).

ciphers.name: aes128-cbc
ciphers.reason: AES-128 (2001) in CBC mode; prone to padding-oracle attacks without extra mitigations.

ciphers.name: twofish-cbc
ciphers.reason: Twofish (1998) but used in CBC without authentication; better options exist today.

items.summary: The server in Dropbear before 2017.75 might allow post-authentication root remote code execution because of a double free in cleanup of TCP listeners when the -a option is enabled.

Dropbear before 2017.75 might allow local users to read certain files as root, if the file has the authorized_keys file format with a command= option. This occurs because ~/.ssh/authorized_keys is read with root privileges and symlinks are followed.
